stories.text:
This is something that bugs me a little about Hacker News. It's a very minor issue, but I'm bringing it up because it's Hacker News.

Let's say I make a comment, and it has 14 upvotes. That does not mean 14 people saw it and liked it, it means 13 people did. A new submission with 2,834 upvotes only had 2,833 people who actually upvoted it. I know that there are downvotes which make things not a perfect match, but I don't think that affects my view.

In my ideal world, every submission and comment would start at 0. And they'd either go up or down from there.

This would also be adjusted in the "fading" for downvoted comments, with them starting to fade at -2 instead of -1.
stories.title: Ask HN: Could we decrease the HN points counter to 0 for new comments?

Hi HN,

I am thinking of making a dedicated server box for your home that runs self-hosted apps. Wait, you say... isn't that just a computer running Ubuntu? Yes, but hear me out --

The idea would be to have a physical box (that you can see & trust) in your living room. Installing a self-hosted app (such as Peertube, Mastodon, email, etc.) takes one click. All the Docker stuff will happen automatically. DNS/domain configuration will happen automatically. And suddenly you have your own little self-hosted universe without trusting any external EC2/GCP/etc. (There are some constraints on traffic; if you host a popular PeerTube your ISP might get a bit sad. That can be resolved later.)

All of this is possible & relatively easy to do now. It's just schleppy. And it breaks a lot.

If I made something that "just worked", would you buy it?

stories.text:
With 2021 the worst year for worker productivity, it has to be asked: is this largely because work-from-home isn't working out?

We can find lots of excuses (resignations; worker malaise; economic decline) but isn't most of that laid right back at the door of work-from-home?

When just a few are involved it may be viable. But I'm beginning to think, it will never fly to have almost everybody staying home. Something critical about the work environment gets broken, when nobody is minding the shop.
